title: Japan Failed to Track N.Korean Missiles
text:
Japan failed to track the trajectories of several short-range ballistic missiles North had fired since May, according to Kyodo News on Monday.

Kyodo quoted Japanese government officials as admitting that military radars failed to pick up the trajectories of at least two of about a dozen missiles launched by North Korea from May to September.

The report comes after South Korea decided to scrap a military intelligence-sharing pact with Japan amid a growing spat between the neighbors.

Yoji Koda, a former commander of the Japan Self-Defense Fleet, said that the paths of missiles are easy to track if intelligence is gathered on their launch sites in advance, and that South Korea is capable of gathering rough intelligence on the location and time of North Korean missile launches with its surveillance equipment.

But he added Seoul probably failed to share such intelligence with Tokyo recently.

In theory the intelligence-sharing pact remains in force until November, so it is unclear whether South Korea violated it. Japan now hopes to gather more intelligence with the help of American civilian satellites as the pact with Seoul expires, the Yomiuri Shimbun reported.
description: Japan Failed to Track N.Korean Missiles
